A wisdom and prudence that is not understood by the disbelievers, or they do not want to understand it. That wisdom and prudence is that Allah will not allow His servants to do as they please. Allah has explained through His messengers that whoever commits evil or injustice will be rewarded with a fitting recompense, both in this world and in the Hereafter. If a servant has not received retribution in this world for his evil deeds because of his position or cleverness in concealing the evil, then he will surely receive his recompense in the Hereafter.

Likewise, are the servants of Allah who do good. This is the wisdom and prudence of Allah, the Most Just, the All-Knowing of all the deeds of His servants. On the Day of Resurrection, all the deeds of mankind will receive a just reward, even if they have already been punished in this world, especially for the servants of Allah who have not yet received their recompense. Denying the Day of Judgment and the Day of Recompense means denying the wisdom and prudence of Allah, the Most Just and Almighty.

Then Allah explains that He knows everything that exists and happens in the heavens and on earth, nothing is hidden from Him, even as small as a *zarrah* (atom) because all of that has been recorded in *Lauh Mahfudh*. Let no servant think that his actions, however small or tightly covered and hidden, escape the knowledge of Allah. He surely knows it and will recompense that action, both in this world and the Hereafter, according to His wisdom, prudence, and justice.
text.4:
As for those who believe, they believe in the Day of Resurrection and prove their faith by performing righteous deeds and avoiding actions forbidden by Allah. They will obtain forgiveness from Allah, the Most Forgiving. Allah will forgive their mistakes and erase their sins in accordance with His word:

"Indeed, good deeds do away with misdeeds. That is a reminder for those who remember (Allah)." (Hud/11: 114)
text.5:
Conversely, those who deny the verses of Allah, strive to hinder others from believing in Allah and His Messenger, and deny the Day of Resurrection and mock those who believe in it, think that they will escape the punishment of Allah. Because of their arrogance and denial, they will receive a very painful punishment and will be thrown into Hellfire (Jahim). Such is the wisdom and justice of Allah in providing the Day of Resurrection so that people receive recompense according to their deeds. It is impossible for Allah to equate His servants who do good with His servants who do evil. Allah says in the verse below:

"Shall We treat those who believe and do righteous deeds like those who spread corruption on earth? Or shall We treat those who fear Allah like those who are wicked?" (Shad/38: 28)

And His saying:

"Not equal are the companions of the Fire and the companions of Paradise. It is the companions of Paradise who will be the successful." (Al-Hashr/59: 20)
text.6: Allah explains that, unlike the disbelievers who refuse to use their reason and intellect and a priori reject what the Qur'an proclaims, some of the People of the Book, such as 'Abdullah bin Salam, Ka'ab, and others, acknowledge that what is proclaimed in the Qur'an about the coming of the Day of Judgment is true and cannot be doubted. They also acknowledge that the Qur'an is guidance from Allah to the straight path that must be followed by mankind to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. Within the Qur'an are laws, regulations, and rules that are in accordance with human nature (fitrah) and their environment, and will certainly bring happiness.
text.7:
In this verse, Allah explains the denial of the disbelievers regarding the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection and how intense their mockery and ridicule were towards the Prophet Muhammad, who announced it. They questioned each other about a man who said that if they died and were buried, then their bodies and bones had disintegrated, they would then be brought back to life to account for their deeds. The man who said this was Muhammad, who claimed that he received revelation from his Lord. They considered this a great opportunity for them to influence public opinion and discredit the Prophet, saying that he was insane or fabricating a great lie against Allah by saying that the news was a revelation revealed to him. Perhaps most ordinary people would be influenced by the mockery and ridicule, so that they would look down on and despise the Prophet.

Therefore, Allah affirms in this verse that those who do not believe in the Hereafter will receive torment and be in manifest error. They will receive torment both in this world and in the Hereafter. In this world, they will become lost people in the midst of their life's journey, not knowing which direction to go, and always in anxiety and doubt. People who have no creed and do not believe in the justice of Allah and the Hereafter will always be tossed about in confusion. They have no hope of obtaining Allah's justice because what they encounter and see in this world is full of imbalance and injustice. The weak become prey for the strong. Whereas those who believe, who fully believe in the justice of Allah and the existence of the reckoning of human deeds in the Hereafter, will certainly be fully convinced that if they are oppressed, Allah will repay those who oppress them with a fitting reward. If not in this world, then in the Hereafter that retribution will surely be carried out. In fact, in the Hereafter, Allah will give a manifold reward for their patience and reliance (tawakkal). Belief in the existence of the Hereafter is a blessing for a servant of Allah.
text.8:
In this verse, Allah explains the denial of the disbelievers regarding the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection and how intense their mockery and ridicule were towards the Prophet Muhammad, who announced it. They asked each other about a man who said that if they died and were buried, then their bodies and bones were completely destroyed, they would then be brought back to life to account for their deeds. The man who said this was Muhammad, who claimed that he received revelation from his Lord. They considered this a great opportunity for them to influence public opinion and discredit the Prophet, saying that he was mad or fabricating a great lie against Allah by saying that the news was a revelation revealed to him. Perhaps most laypeople would be influenced by the mockery and ridicule so that they would look down on and despise the Prophet.

Therefore, Allah affirms in this verse that those who do not believe in the Hereafter will receive torment and be in manifest error. They will receive torment both in this world and in the Hereafter. In this world, they will be people who are lost in the midst of their life's journey, not knowing which direction to go, and always in anxiety and doubt. People who have no creed and do not believe in the justice of Allah and the Hereafter will always be tossed about in confusion. They have no hope of obtaining Allah's justice because what they encounter and see in this world is full of imbalance and injustice. The weak become prey for the strong. Meanwhile, those who believe, who fully believe in the justice of Allah and the reckoning of human deeds in the Hereafter, will certainly be fully convinced that if they are oppressed, Allah will repay those who oppress them with a fitting reward. If not in this world, then in the Hereafter that retribution will surely be carried out. In fact, in the Hereafter, Allah will give manifold rewards for their patience and reliance (tawakkal). Belief in the existence of the Hereafter is a blessing for a servant of Allah.
text.9:
In this verse, Allah warns those who disbelieve in the occurrence of the Day of Judgment and commands them to pay attention to the natural events they witness themselves. How many natural disasters occur in various countries, such as devastating earthquakes that destroy buildings, causing invaluable loss of life and property, and massive floods that sweep away houses, people, animals, and plants.

According to scientific studies, because the sky is spherical, wherever humans stand on Earth, the sky will always be in front of and behind them, as well as above and below them. This excerpt of the verse also indicates that the shape of the Earth is round.

Clumps from the sky can be interpreted as fragments of celestial bodies (planets, stars, comets, etc.) after colliding with each other. These fragments are known as asteroids, meteorites, and so on. Every day, the Earth's surface is bombarded by these rocky fragments, which can cause damage to the Earth and its inhabitants. Because Allah is the Most Gracious and Most Merciful, He protects the Earth with a shield in the form of an air layer called the atmosphere. This air layer acts like a brake, dampening the movement of these "bombs" through friction that occurs when they come into contact with asteroids or meteorites. It can even destroy them directly because the asteroid or meteorite is destroyed or completely burned up due to the heat generated by friction with the Earth's atmosphere.

Another protective shield is the ozone layer, the Earth's magnetic field that brakes charged fragments. If the ozone layer is torn due to air pollution, fragments of celestial bodies will fall plunging to Earth, and could hit humans or bury them into the Earth's surface.

History records how Allah destroyed several past peoples, and the remnants of their civilizations can still be seen today. Do all these things not make them realize that if Allah wills, He can sink their land into the ground, and can also send celestial bodies such as meteors or planets to collide with the Earth, and thus a catastrophe will occur that is unimaginable in its magnitude. Do they not take lessons from these natural events or from events written in history and the remnants that they can still witness themselves? For those whose hearts are illuminated by the light of faith, these various events increase their faith and make them believe that Allah is All-Powerful, and that they will ultimately return to Allah, the Owner and Ruler of the heavens and the earth, the All-Wise and All-Just.
text.10:
Among the blessings Allah bestowed upon Prophet David was his exceptionally melodious voice. It is narrated that Prophet David was a composer or creator of religious songs. When David glorified and praised Allah with his melodious voice, especially when the songs also depicted the greatness, glory, and majesty of God, the surrounding nature echoed as if it were also glorifying Allah, following the rhythm of his voice. We do not know how the surrounding nature glorified and sang along with David as Allah commanded him. Indeed, this cannot be known by humans, as stated in His word:

"The seven heavens and the earth and whatever is in them exalt Allah. And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Him] by His praise, but you do not understand their [way of] exalting. Indeed, He is ever Forbearing and Forgiving." (al-Isra'/17: 44)

Regarding the beauty and melodiousness of David's voice, it is narrated in a sahih hadith:

From 'Aisha, she said: The Messenger of Allah (saw) heard the recitation of Abu Musa al-Ash'ari, then he said, "Indeed, this man has been granted by Allah a melodious voice like the family of David." (Narrated by an-Nasa'i)

Another blessing that Allah bestowed upon David was that he could make hard iron as soft as wax so that it could be formed into tools, especially war tools. With the miracle that Allah bestowed, David did this without heating it with fire, as people are able to do.
text.11:
Then Allah commanded Prophet David to make special armor from soft iron, unlike the armor known at that time. Usually, armor at that time was made from thin pieces of iron arranged like clothing, but this armor greatly bothered the wearer, besides causing heat to the body and restricting movement. However, the armor made by David, because the iron had become soft, was very different from ordinary armor. The armor was made like rolls of chains arranged neatly so that the armor followed the body's movements. Thus, the wearer could move freely without feeling any disturbance. With that soft armor, David could make new weapons to defend his kingdom from enemy attacks.

Then, to be grateful for the blessings He had given, Allah also commanded David and his people to always do good deeds and use all the blessings that Allah had bestowed to achieve His pleasure. He always sees and knows what His servants do.
text.12:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah subjected the wind to Prophet Sulaiman so that it could carry him to the places he desired with great speed. In just half a day, the wind could carry him to a place that was a month's journey away, whether that journey was from morning until noon or from noon until sunset.

Qatadah, in interpreting this verse, stated, "The wind could carry Sulaiman from morning until the sun passed its zenith a distance of a month's journey, and from the sun's passing its zenith until sunset a distance of a month's journey as well." In this regard, al-Hasan al-Bashri said, "Sulaiman once set out riding the wind, from Damascus to Istakhr, then he descended there for lunch, then he set out again to Kabul to spend the night there. Whereas the distance between Damascus and Istakhr is a month's journey for a fast traveler, and the distance between Istakhr and Kabul is also a month's journey."

Another favor that Allah bestowed upon Sulaiman was softening copper like wax, making it easy to shape according to the desires of those who processed it. This is similar to the favor given to Prophet Daud, which was softening iron.

Among those favors was also subjecting the jinn to work making whatever Sulaiman desired. The jinn were always obedient and compliant in following his commands, because they were threatened by Allah with a painful punishment if they did not fulfill Sulaiman's commands.
text.13:
Therefore, they diligently carried out what Solomon commanded, such as building places of worship, beautiful statues made of wood, copper, glass, and marble, as well as large cauldrons for cooking food sufficient for dozens of people. Because of their size and breadth, these vessels looked like pools of water. They also made large cooking pots for Solomon, so large that they could not be lifted or moved. Because the jinn possessed tremendous strength, they easily made everything Solomon desired, such as building magnificent and luxurious palaces, and digging canals for irrigation, so that Solomon's kingdom became famous as a great and most prosperous kingdom, unmatched by any kingdom at that time. This was a realization of his prayer that was granted by God, as mentioned in His word:

"He said, "My Lord, forgive me and grant me a kingdom such as will not belong to anyone after me. Indeed, You are the Bestower." So We subjected to him the wind blowing gently by his command wherever he directed, And the devils - every builder and diver." (Shad/38: 35-37)

Then Allah commanded Solomon, as a member of the family of David, to be grateful for the blessings that Allah had bestowed upon him. Being grateful for Allah's blessings is not just a matter of saying it, but must be accompanied by righteous deeds and using those blessings for things that please Him.

It is narrated by at-Tirmidhi that the Prophet Muhammad ascended the pulpit and recited this verse. Then he said, "There are three qualities if possessed by a person, it means he has been given a bounty like the bounty given to the family of David." We asked him, "What are those qualities?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "First: Being just, whether in anger or in happiness. Second: Always living simply, whether in poverty or wealth. Third: Always fearing Allah, whether in solitude or in the presence of many people."

Allah accompanied His command for Solomon to be grateful for the blessings he received by explaining that very few of His servants are truly grateful to Him. How a servant is grateful to his Lord can be seen from the way the Prophet (saw) was grateful to Allah.

From 'Aisha that the Messenger of Allah prayed at night until the soles of his feet swelled, so I ('Aisha) said to him, "Why do you do this when Allah has forgiven your past and future sins?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "Should I not be a grateful servant?" (Narrated by Muslim)
text.14:
This verse explains that when his death was near, Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon) was sitting on his throne, leaning on his staff. It was at that time that Sulaiman died, and no one knew that he had died, neither his guards, the inhabitants of the palace, nor the jinn who were always working hard carrying out his commands. He fell prostrate because his staff was eaten by termites, so it could not support his weight. Only then did people realize that Sulaiman had died, as did the jinn who continued to work hard carrying out his commands. At that time, they acknowledged their weakness, because they could not know that Sulaiman had died. If they had known that Sulaiman had died, they certainly would not have continued to work hard, because they were only commanded by Allah to obey Prophet Sulaiman, not the dignitaries in his palace. Allah does not explain in this verse how long Sulaiman leaned on his staff until he fell prostrate.

Some *mufassirun* (Quran commentators) say that Prophet Sulaiman leaned on his staff until he died for one year. They say that Prophet Daud (David) had begun building Baitul Maqdis (the Holy Temple) but could not complete its construction. When his death was near, he bequeathed to Prophet Sulaiman to complete its construction. Prophet Sulaiman ordered the jinn who were under his power to complete the building. When Sulaiman felt that his death was near, he wanted to hide his death from the jinn who were working hard to complete their work. Then Prophet Sulaiman leaned on his staff so that if he died, people would think he was still alive because he was still sitting leaning on his staff. Finally, the staff was eaten by termites and broke. At that time, it was only known that Prophet Sulaiman had died.

They wanted to know how long Sulaiman leaned on the staff after he died, by taking the remnants. After they calculated, it turned out that the termites only ate a small part of the staff in a day and night, so it took a year to damage it.

Some *ahli tafsir* (experts in Quranic exegesis) are of the opinion that Sulaiman leaned on his staff until he died. Indeed, the staff had long been eaten by termites without Sulaiman knowing. When Sulaiman leaned on the staff when his death arrived, the staff was already rotten. It is impossible for a king to be left alone by his family and guards without food and drink, without asking him about important matters that require his opinion.

Which of these two opinions is correct, we cannot know. In the stories of the prophets, many things happen that cannot be reached by human thought because they are given miracles by Allah. If Prophet Sulaiman leaned for only a short time and then collapsed, the jinn would certainly not regret it so greatly because they had already worked to complete Baitul Maqdis.
text.15:
In the southern part of Yemen resided a people called Saba'. They occupied a very fertile area, so they lived prosperously and had achieved a high level of civilization. They were able to control the heavy rainfall that occurred during certain seasons by building a giant dam that could store water for the dry season. The dam could be said to be a natural dam because it was located between two hills, and at its end, a tall structure was erected to prevent water from flowing wastefully into the desert. They made water gates that, when opened, could channel water to the areas they desired. This dam was known as the Ma'rib Dam or the al-'Arim Dam.

Many historians and researchers in the West doubted the existence of the Ma'rib Dam. Finally, a researcher from France came to southern Yemen himself to investigate the remnants of the dam in 1843. He was able to prove the existence of the dam by finding its remains, then photographing and sending the images to a magazine in France. Other researchers also found several stone inscriptions among the ruins of the dam. Thus, they became increasingly convinced that in ancient times, a kingdom that was advanced, prosperous, and highly civilized had stood in southern Yemen.

In this verse, Allah explains a glimpse about the people of Saba' who inhabited the southern region of Yemen. They occupied a vast and fertile valley thanks to the regular irrigation from the Ma'rib Dam. To the left and right of their area stretched vast and fertile gardens that produced abundant food and fruits.

The people of Saba' initially worshipped the sun, but after Queen Balqis took over the leadership of the kingdom, they became believers by following the teachings brought by Prophet Solomon. This is narrated in the Al-Qur'an as follows:

"But he (the hoopoe) stayed not long, and said: "I have compassed (territory) which thou hast not compassed, and I have come to thee from Saba' with tidings true. "I found (there) a woman ruling over them, and she has been given (abundance) of all things, and she has a magnificent throne. "I found her and her people worshipping the sun besides Allah: Satan has made their deeds fair-seeming to them, and has barred them from the Path,- so that they receive no guidance." (an-Naml/27: 22-24)

However, over time, the people of Saba' became arrogant and forgot that the prosperity they possessed was a gift from the Almighty and Most Gracious. Allah, through His messenger, commanded them to be grateful to Him for all the blessings and favors bestowed upon them. Their land became fertile and prosperous thanks to the grace of Allah, the Most Forgiving, protecting them from all kinds of dangers and disasters.
text.16:
They rejected and turned away from the call of Allah, even hindering those who realized and believed in Him. Allah then inflicted punishment upon them by breaching the Ma'rib Dam, and a great catastrophe occurred. Their land was struck by a torrential flood, sweeping away everything in its path. The gardens that were on the left and right sides of the land were destroyed, and all their livestock were swept away. The human casualties were countless, so that only a few people remained alive. Only a few small groups of them survived that terrible disaster.

Even those who survived could not live happily in their original place. Some of them then migrated to other fertile places because there were no more gardens that they could cultivate well and not many more livestock that they could raise. The lands that were once fertile had become barren because all the water stored in the dam had spilled into the desert, which could swallow any amount of water. What grew in the former gardens were only plants that were not very useful, and their fruits were bitter. If they wanted to cultivate, they could only hope for rain from the sky.
text.17: Thus, the sunnatullah (Allah's established way) has been applied to the people of Saba' just as it was applied to the arrogant and rebellious communities before them, who refused to accept the truth, and always rejected and opposed the teachings of Allah brought by His messengers. Thus, Allah inflicted torment and disaster upon the disbelieving people who denied and were ungrateful for the blessings bestowed upon them.
text.18:
The people of Saba', who still remained in their land, even though they experienced hardship because their land had become barren and arid, traveled to trade from one country to another, especially to larger countries, such as Mecca and Syria in the north and northwest. At that time, these countries were prosperous and were centers of trade. Travel between these countries was easy and safe because there were villages where travelers could stop if they were overtaken by night, ran out of supplies, or felt tired.

They were able to survive and also cultivate crops modestly during the rainy season. They also raised livestock when there were still many pastures. This was a blessing from Allah to them, although not as great as the blessing He bestowed when the Ma'rib Dam had not yet been destroyed and vanished. Allah commanded them to use that blessing in the best possible way and to travel with merchandise between countries safely, even though the distance they traveled was sometimes very far. They could stop in the villages around the big cities when they felt tired. If they were overtaken by night, they could stop at the nearest village, and so on.
text.19:
Therefore, they asked Allah that along the journey between one land and another, there would be no resting places to stop and rest, so that the journey had to be continued even if it meant suffering various kinds of difficulties. This was their nature and the nature of arrogant people; having received ease, they actually desired hardship and suffering. It was no different from the Children of Israel who had been given good food by Allah, namely Manna and Salwa, then they asked for ordinary food, as mentioned in His word:

And (remember) when you said, "O Moses, we can never endure one [kind of] food. So call upon your Lord to bring forth for us from the earth its green herbs and its cucumbers and its garlic and its lentils and its onions." He said, "Would you exchange what is better for what is less? Go down to [any] city and indeed, you will find what you want." And they were covered with humiliation and misery and returned with anger from Allah. (al-Baqarah/2: 61)

Actually, with that request, the people of Saba' had wronged themselves and were not satisfied with the bounty that Allah had bestowed upon them. They had forgotten that Allah destroyed their fertile and prosperous land only because they did not want to believe and be grateful for Allah's bounty. Therefore, Allah fulfilled their request by eliminating resting places on their journey, making it difficult for them to trade, and their lives became difficult.

They had to migrate to other lands, leaving their land and scattering here and there. The Jafnah bin Amr tribe was forced to stay in the land of Sham, Aus and Khazraj in Medina, and Azad (Uman) lived in Oman. Likewise, other tribes. Their existence as a nation that was once very famous as a noble nation with high civilization and culture disappeared. What remained were only stories narrated from mouth to mouth, and their fame only became a source of entertainment, discussed when they stayed up at night.

Indeed, what the people of Saba' experienced should be a lesson for everyone who is patient and knows how to be grateful for every blessing they receive from Allah. Every servant must be grateful to Allah for all His blessings and be patient in accepting His trials. In fact, he must be grateful to Allah even when he receives trials from Him.

It was narrated by Sa'ad bin Abi Waqqash that the Messenger of Allah said:

I admire Allah's decree for a believer. If he receives goodness, he praises and is grateful to Him. If he is afflicted with calamity, he praises and is grateful to Him. The believer receives reward in everything, even just a morsel of food that he gives to his wife. (Riwayat Ahmad)
text.20:
In this verse, Allah explains that Iblis assumed that the people of Saba', whom Allah had destroyed along with their land, had followed him and obediently carried out his deceptions. He assumed they had disobeyed Allah and were ungrateful for all the blessings bestowed upon them, except for a few believers who remained steadfast in their faith and did not accept his deceptions. Thus, Iblis assumed that he could control humanity and lead them to the path of error, as he had declared before Allah. This is mentioned in His saying:

"(Iblis) said, 'By Your might, I will surely mislead them all, except, among them, Your chosen servants.'" (Shad/38: 82-83)
text.21:
Allah rejects and nullifies Iblis's untrue presumption. Allah affirms that Satan has no power whatsoever over humans to mislead them, causing them to disobey Him. Satan's deception is merely a test from Allah for His servants, to see whether they will be deceived by Satan's enticements or reject them completely, so that they do not affect their faith and piety in the slightest.

Al-Hasan al-Bashri is of the opinion that Satan never strikes humans with a stick and never forces them to do anything. Satan's actions are merely acts of deception, enticing with empty hopes, and then humans accept them. Satan's deception is only like that, no different from bacteria that attack humans during the season of disease outbreaks. Whoever does not have strong resistance in their body to withstand the attack of the disease becomes its victim. But, the disease will not be able to overcome a person in whose body there are strong elements of resistance. He will remain healthy and well even though many people have fallen ill or died because of it. If someone falls into Satan's trap, then he should not blame others; the one who is at fault and weak in this matter is himself. Therefore, every human being must fortify himself with strong faith, with piety, and always do good deeds.

Allah's word:

"And I had no authority over you except that I invited you, and you responded to me. So do not blame me; but blame yourselves. I cannot help you, nor can you help me. Indeed, I disavow your associating me [with Allah] before." Indeed, for the wrongdoers is a painful punishment. (Ibrahim/14: 22)

Allah then affirms to the Prophet Muhammad that He records all human actions, nothing is hidden from Him, not even the size of an atom (zarrah). He will reckon human actions with the utmost justice, and no one will be harmed in this matter; in fact, He will reward good deeds with multiplied rewards.
text.22:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to challenge the polytheists of Mecca: if their idols and objects of worship truly possess any power, even the slightest, let them prove it by providing examples of what they have created or what they own. Can these idols provide assistance to them or repel dangers that threaten them? Of course, they cannot provide such evidence, because it is impossible for inanimate objects that they made with their own hands to create anything or to help and ward off harm from them.

Therefore, Allah affirms that these idols do not possess even the slightest power (not even the size of a *zarrah*) over the heavens, the earth, and what is contained within them, and they have absolutely no ability to help them. How can they worship them if they use their minds? In another verse, Allah also affirms this with His saying:

"And those whom you invoke [or worship] other than Allah do not possess [as much as] the membrane of a date seed." (Fathir/35: 13)

They do not possess anything on their own or in partnership with others, and there is nothing that cooperates with them in creating or owning anything. This is a fact that we see in the world.
text.23:
In the afterlife, idols will not be able to help them from hardship. Nor is it possible for them to intercede, because on that day no one can intercede except with the permission of Allah. Is it possible that Allah would permit idols, which are the cause of the misguidance of His servants, to intercede? Intercession will not be granted by Allah except to the prophets, angels, and His servants who are deemed worthy of being granted intercession. Allah says:

"No one can intercede with Him except by His permission." (al-Baqarah/2: 255)

"And how many angels there are in the heavens whose intercession is of no avail except after Allah has permitted [it] for whom He wills and approves." (an-Najm/53: 36)

On that day, the servants of Allah wait with feelings of anxiety and impatience, wondering who among them will be permitted by Him to intercede and who will receive intercession. At that time, they are all silent because fear has left their hearts, and Allah will give His decree. They wait with hope and wonder among themselves what the Lord has said. All answer, "What Allah has said is the word of truth, that His intercession will be given to whomever He approves of, because He is the Most High and the Most Great." At that time, the disbelievers realize that they will not receive intercession and they know what fate they must experience.
text.24:
In this verse, Allah, through the Prophet Muhammad, asks the polytheists who provides them with sustenance from the heavens and the earth by sending down rain, and with that rainwater, the earth becomes fertile and grows various kinds of plants to become food for them and their livestock. They certainly cannot answer it. Even if they wanted to say Allah, an answer that aligns with their conscience, they answer with idols, an answer that actually contradicts their conscience which affirms the call of the Prophet Muhammad. Therefore, they remain silent, unable to provide any answer. Thus, Allah commands Muhammad that the one who provides sustenance from both the heavens and the earth is only Allah. A similar question is also mentioned in another verse:

Say, "Who is the Lord of the heavens and earth?" Say, "Allah." Say, "Have you then taken besides Him allies who cannot benefit themselves or avert harm?" (ar-Ra'd/13: 16)

Allah then instructs the Prophet Muhammad to say to them, after they are unable to answer the above question, "And either we or you are rightly guided or in clear error." This is a very subtle and sharp way of discussion. The Prophet does not say that it is the polytheists who are misguided and he who is right, but he states that one of the two must be following the right path and one is following the path of error. This statement will surely attract the opponent to think about who is actually guided and who is misguided, and avoids harsh methods because they will bring harsh answers as well. If the Prophet (saw) had stated firmly that they were misguided, they would certainly have answered firmly that the Prophet was misguided.
text.25:
In this verse, the Prophet Muhammad is instructed to tell them that each individual is fully responsible for all their actions. The polytheists are not responsible for the wrongdoings of the Muslims, and conversely, the Muslims are not responsible for the actions of the polytheists. Some commentators (mufasir) say that the polytheists once accused the Prophet (saw) and the believers of having committed a great sin by apostatizing and betraying the religion of their ancestors. As an answer to this accusation, it is stated that the Muslims are indeed responsible for all their sins and mistakes. Likewise, the polytheists are also fully responsible for all their actions, whether good or bad. In another verse, Allah instructs the Prophet to say words similar to this, as in His saying:

"And if they deny you (Muhammad), then say, "For me is my deed, and for you is your deed. You are disassociated from what I do, and I am disassociated from what you do." (Yunus/10: 41)
text.26:
Then the Prophet was commanded to say to the polytheists, "Allah will gather us all on the Day of Judgment, and there He will give a decision regarding us and our deeds with the utmost justice. There it will be clear who among us is misguided and who is on the straight path, who among us is wrong and who is right."

All the deeds of His servants will be weighed on the scales of justice. Bad deeds will be recompensed with a fitting reward, and good deeds will be rewarded with multiplied rewards. This is also clearly stated in another verse, namely:

And on the day the Hour occurs - that is the day the people will be separated. As for those who believed and did righteous deeds, they will be in a garden [of Paradise], delighted. But as for those who disbelieved and denied Our verses and the meeting of the Hereafter - those will remain in the punishment [of Hell]. (ar-Rum/30: 14-16)

There, Allah will give the decision, and no one can dispute it because all decisions are based on real facts that cannot be denied. Allah is All-Knowing when the verdict will be issued by Him; no servant can know, because He is the Ultimate Judge and the All-Knowing.
text.27:
Allah then commanded the Prophet Muhammad to ask those polytheists, who and what exactly were the idols they associated with Allah. They were asked to explain to him who these idols were, what their characteristics were, their value and quality, and their position. Why were they made objects of worship, were they indeed worthy of being worshipped?

These questions were posed to them as a challenge and a statement that they were not using their intellect because they were worshipping something worthless, inanimate objects that they made with their own hands. It is absolutely impossible and illogical to associate inanimate objects with Allah, the All-Powerful and All-Knowing.
text.28:
In this verse, Allah explains that Prophet Muhammad was sent to all of mankind. His duty was to bring good news to those who believe in and practice the message he brought, and at the same time, to bring a warning to those who deny or reject his teachings. Prophet Muhammad is the final prophet; no prophet or messenger will be sent by Allah after him. Thus, the message he brought must be valid for all of mankind until the Day of Judgment. As the final message, it contains regulations and laws that are appropriate and good to be implemented in every place and time.

The message brought by Prophet Muhammad originates from Allah, the All-Wise and All-Knowing. The Lord who created the heavens and the earth and everything in between. He is the One who regulates everything in them. He regulates all of it with very precise regulations so that everything runs well and harmoniously. Allah, whose power is so great, would not send a message encompassing all of mankind if the regulations and laws did not encompass all of mankind's interests at all times. Thus, His message must be a good message to be applied to anyone and any people in this world. Many verses in the Al-Qur'an affirm that Muhammad was sent to all of mankind.

"Blessed is He who sent down al-Furqan (the Qur'an) to His servant (Muhammad) that he may be a warner to the worlds (of jinn and men)." (al-Furqan/25: 1)

And His saying:

"Say, [O Muhammad], "O mankind, indeed I am the Messenger of Allah to you all, [from Him] to whom belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. There is no deity except Him; He gives life and causes death." So believe in Allah and His Messenger, the unlettered prophet, who believes in Allah and His words, and follow him that you may be guided." (al-A'raf/7: 158)

This is not known by everyone; in fact, most people reject and challenge it. Among those who challenge it are Muhammad's own people, namely the disbelievers of Mecca.

"And most of the people, although you strive for it, are not believers." (Yusuf/12: 103)
text.29:
In this verse, Allah explains that the polytheists opposed Prophet Muhammad as a bearer of good news for the believers and a warner for those who disbelieve. Muhammad explained to them that Allah's justice is not only applicable in this world but also encompasses justice in the Hereafter. All of humanity's actions will be recompensed with appropriate rewards. They mocked the Prophet's words and said that the Day of Judgment was impossible and would not happen. They said to him in a mocking tone, "If the Day of Judgment that your Lord promised is really going to happen, then tell us when it will happen." In fact, another verse explains that they challenged Prophet Muhammad to hasten the coming of the Day of Judgment, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"Those who do not believe in it (the Hour) seek to hasten it, while those who believe are fearful of it and know that it is the truth. Unquestionably, those who dispute concerning the Hour are in extreme error." (ash-Shura/42: 18)

Their mockery and challenge show their ignorance about the Prophet Muhammad's duty as a messenger, and they do not know the limits of his duties. The Messenger is only a human being assigned by Allah to convey the message. He is not someone who has power and knowledge like his Lord. His knowledge and power are limited to what Allah has given him. If he is asked about unseen matters, he certainly will not be able to explain them unless Allah has informed him. If he is asked to bring down punishment or hasten the coming of the Day of Judgment, then that is beyond his ability.
text.30: As an answer to the denial and challenge of the polytheists, Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to affirm to them that the Day of Judgment will definitely occur at the time that Allah has determined. When its time arrives, the Day of Judgment cannot be postponed or brought forward even for a moment. Therefore, they must be careful, always vigilant, and prepare themselves with faith and righteous deeds. If the time of the Day of Judgment has come, there will be no more opportunity for a person to repent, and he will regret it later when he sees the torment prepared for those who disbelieve.
text.31:
In this verse, Allah explains how deeply the polytheists disbelieved in the religion brought by Prophet Muhammad, as well as the other heavenly religions brought by previous messengers. They declared their determination not to believe in the Qur'an and the books revealed by Allah to His messengers. For people who are determined like this, there is no argument or evidence that they can accept, even if the evidence is strong, clear, and acceptable to sound reason or a clear mind.

Their hearts have been filled with rigid fanaticism, so that everything that contradicts their understanding is wrong, misguided, and completely unacceptable. The polytheists of Mecca once asked the People of the Book about the characteristics and qualities of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and whether these were mentioned in their books. Some of the People of the Book explained the characteristics and qualities of Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). They also said that perhaps Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) was indeed a messenger sent by God. For people whose hearts are pure and not tainted by arrogance and blind fanaticism, this answer would make them realize and make them think. However, the answer made them angry and they flatly rejected the explanation of the People of the Book and refused to believe it. Indeed, their inner selves have been closed to receiving the truth, as mentioned in Allah's word:

Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment. (al-Baqarah/2: 7)

Because there is no evidence that can make them realize, and what should be presented to them is a severe threat, these verses tell about the condition of the disbelievers and their leaders in the afterlife when they stand before Allah. At that time, the disbelievers realize that they have been misguided. They turn to their leaders and say, "If it were not for your actions towards us in the world, we would not have experienced such a thing. We would have believed in Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and been among Allah's servants who are pleased with Him."
text.32:
This statement and accusation were answered by the leaders who had misled them, seeking to evade responsibility. Those leaders said, "Did we ever hinder you from following guidance? We never forced you to follow our will and follow the path we took. We never prevented you from following the teachings brought by the Messenger of Allah. It was only you yourselves, with your own will, who rejected those teachings and participated in denying them. If you have gone astray because of your actions, do not bring us into it to be held accountable for your deeds. You were actually among the astray."

If those leaders had uttered that answer while they were still in the world, their followers would surely have been silent, because of their great influence over them. However, it is different in the Hereafter. The position of people before Allah is all the same; there are no subordinates and leaders, and there are no feudal lords or commoners.
text.33:
Therefore, the followers were not satisfied with the answers of their leaders and continued their accusations that the leaders had always persuaded and deceived them day and night, and commanded them to disbelieve in Allah and associate partners with Him. But, everything was already too late and there was no more time to return to the truth or to repent.

Everyone, both the leaders and their followers, knew that they would receive a fitting recompense for their disbelief and disobedience. They felt great regret when they saw the punishment that would be inflicted upon them, but that regret was of no use anymore. They were thrown into hell in a state of being shackled. Indeed, that was the appropriate punishment to be inflicted because of their attitudes and actions during their time in the world.
text.34:
In this verse, it is emphasized that there is no prophet sent by Allah to a land who did not face opposition from the leaders of his people. They are usually the elite who control the political and economic life of that land. They are well-established, live luxuriously, and indulge in extravagance. With the arrival of the prophets, they feel their established way of life is disturbed by the teachings brought by these prophets.

Religion does not justify those in power oppressing the weak, while their established position is maintained by suppressing the weak. Religion asks people to pay attention to what is lawful (halal) and unlawful (haram) in seeking sustenance and utilizing wealth, while their wealth is obtained by any means, legal or illegal, and that wealth is used for extravagance. Religion does not allow violating religious rules, while their lives are lived without regard for those norms. Therefore, they oppose the prophets and loudly declare, "We oppose what you teach!" This statement also affirms their arrogance, and further encourages them to act arbitrarily (fusuq) on earth. When people act arbitrarily, it becomes a reason for Allah to show His power, namely to destroy them. Allah says:

And when We intend to destroy a city, We command its affluent ones [to obey Allah], but they commit debauchery therein; so the word [of judgment] comes into effect upon it, and We destroy it with [complete] destruction. (al-Isra'/17:16)
text.35:
The tyrannical, arrogant, and arbitrary ruling class boasted of their wealth and lineage. They said, "We are rich and our descendants are numerous, we will not be touched by punishment (affected by the law)." With wealth, they felt they could buy anything. With lineage and supporters, they assumed that their power over the weak could be maintained from generation to generation. They also felt loved by Allah so that they would not be punished in the afterlife for their sins. The benchmark they used was the pleasure of life in this world. The pleasure of life, in their view, indicated that they were loved, while the misery of life indicated that they were hated by Allah.

All their assumptions were incorrect. The giving of abundant wealth and successful children to the disbelievers is not an indication that Allah loves them, but on the contrary, as stated in the following verse:

Do they think that because We extend to them wealth and children, We are hastening to them with good things? Nay, but they perceive not. (al-Mu'minun/23: 55-56)

Even so, punishment is not immediately inflicted on the disbelievers in this world because Allah still gives them a reprieve. This is intended to give them an opportunity to repent, as stated in Allah's word:

And if Allah were to punish men for their wrongdoing, He would not leave on earth a single creature, but He defers them to an appointed term; and when their term comes, they cannot remain behind an hour, nor can they go before (it). (an-Nahl/16: 61)

In another verse, it is explained that wealth and children are a test for humans, whether they remain faithful and grateful or disbelieve. Allah says:

Your wealth and your children are only a trial, whereas Allah - with Him is a great reward. (at-Tagabun/64: 15)

Indeed, wealth for the disbelievers will not make them eternal in this world, but on the contrary, will cause them to be thrown into hell, as Allah says:

He thinks that his wealth will make him immortal. (al-Humazah/104: 3)
text.36:
In this verse, Allah asks Prophet Muhammad to affirm to the leaders of the disbelieving Meccans that it is Allah who expands and restricts sustenance. This is to refute the view of the disbelievers that worldly prosperity is a sign of Allah's affection and hardship is a sign of His hatred.

Allah expands or restricts a person's sustenance according to His wisdom. Allah may expand a person's sustenance because He trusts them to be able to spend some of their wealth on those in need, as stated in the verse:

Indeed, mankind was created anxious: When evil touches him, impatient, And when good touches him, withholding [of it], Except the observers of prayer - Those who are constant in their prayer - And those in whose wealth there is a known right For the petitioner and the deprived (al-Ma'arij/70: 19-25)

For those who disbelieve, abundant wealth and numerous, successful offspring are precisely what Allah uses as a reason to punish them. The reason is that the way they acquire and use wealth and educate their offspring is not in accordance with Allah's provisions, as stated in the verse:

So let not their wealth or their children impress you. Allah only intends to punish them through it in worldly life and that their souls should depart [at death] while they are disbelievers. (at-Taubah/9: 55)

Conversely, Allah is also the One who restricts a person's sustenance. For those who believe, the reduction of possessions, family members, and food is to test their patience. If they are patient, Allah will make them happy in this world and the hereafter, as His saying:

And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient, (al-Baqarah/2: 155)

For those whose faith is not strong, the misery of life makes them constantly regret their fate, and eventually leads them to disbelief:

Man is not weary of supplication for good, but if evil touches him, he is in despair and despondent. (Fushshilat/41: 49)

It is clear that both the pleasures and hardships of life are tests from Allah. The pleasure of life is not a measure that Allah loves, and the narrowness of life is not a measure that Allah hates. It could mean the opposite, that the pleasure of life is given by Allah as a test so that the person becomes increasingly mired in denial. The narrowness of life is a way to obtain happiness in the hereafter if the person is steadfast in accepting it. This is the provision that is not known or understood by many people, including the leaders of the disbelieving Meccans.
text.37:
In this verse, it is emphasized to the leaders of the disbelievers of Mecca that it is not wealth and offspring that can bring a person closer to Allah and obtain His love, but rather faith and righteous deeds. Wealth and offspring are only beneficial if they strengthen faith and increase good deeds. Therefore, wealth must be acquired correctly and used correctly as well. Offspring must be educated well so that they become good offspring. Thus, the means to draw closer to Allah and obtain His love are wealth that is acquired and used correctly, and offspring who are well-educated and will preserve and continue their faith and righteous deeds.

In another verse, Allah indeed asks those who believe to seek a way to draw closer to Him, and the way is through righteous deeds:

"O you who have believed, fear Allah and seek the means [wasilah] of nearness to Him, and strive in His cause, that you may succeed." (al-Ma'idah/5: 35)

Only those who believe and perform many righteous deeds will be given a multiplied reward by Allah. In other verses, it is mentioned that the multiplication is at least ten times (al-An'am/6: 160), and some are seven hundred times (al-Baqarah/2: 261).

Those who are given Paradise feel safe, that is, free from the threat of Hell. Moreover, they are satisfied and happy because Allah loves them and they love Him. Allah says:

"Allah will say, "This is the Day when the truthful will benefit from their truthfulness." For them are gardens [in Paradise] beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever, Allah being pleased with them, and they with Him. That is the great attainment." (al-Ma'idah/5: 119)
text.38:
Furthermore, Allah explains about those who do not believe. They strive to weaken the verses of Allah. What is meant is that they are always trying to thwart the mission of Islam so that people do not know, believe in, and practice the teachings of Islam properly. They will be put into hell and punished severely, as stated in another verse:

"(Those) who avert (people) from the way of Allah and desire to make it crooked. And they are disbelievers in the Hereafter. They will not cause failure (to Allah) on earth, nor have they besides Allah any protectors. For them the punishment will be doubled. They could not hear, nor could they see." (Hud/11: 19-20)
text.39:
In this verse, it is emphasized once again that Allah is the One who expands or restricts sustenance. Different from verse 36, this verse emphasizes that it is the sustenance of His servants that is expanded or restricted by Him. This means that a servant of Allah will receive the decree of his sustenance, whether it is expanded or restricted by Allah. Thus, this verse refutes once again that the abundance of sustenance is a sign of Allah's love and its limitation is a sign of Allah's hatred. A servant of Allah will be patient when his sustenance is limited. A servant of Allah, when his sustenance is abundant, will pay attention to others who are in need. He will not be among those who deny the religion or the Day of Judgment, as stated in the following verse:

Have you seen the one who denies the religion? For that is the one who drives away the orphan, and does not encourage the feeding of the poor. (al-Ma'un/107: 1-3)

Helping others, based on this verse, will actually perpetuate wealth, not deplete it. Helping others will not make us poor, but on the contrary, because that help means empowering many people. The empowerment of many people will result in prosperity, while the exploitation of society will impoverish that society. The Messenger of Allah informed that those who help others are prayed for by the angels for an increase in their sustenance, and those who are stingy are prayed for by the angels for the loss of their wealth:

Every morning two angels descend upon the servant of Allah, one of whom prays, "O Allah, grant a replacement to the one who spends in charity." And the other prays, "O Allah, destroy the wealth of the one who refuses to spend in charity." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.40:
In this verse, Allah explains that on the Day of Judgment, all humans will be gathered before Allah to be held accountable for their actions. At that time, the disbelievers who worshipped other than Allah will be brought face to face with those they worshipped in the world. Allah will ask those who were worshipped whether they ever asked people to worship them. Among those questioned will be the angels, because while in the world, there were people who worshipped them. Some people viewed the angels as daughters of Allah, who, because of their maternal nature, would always love their children even if they were wrong. That is why they worshipped them. Allah says:

"And they have made the angels, who are servants of the Most Merciful, females. Did they witness their creation? Their testimony will be recorded, and they will be questioned. And they say, "If the Most Merciful had willed, we would not have worshipped them." They have no knowledge of that. They are only guessing." (az-Zukhruf/43: 19-20)

The angels and their worshippers are brought together not because Allah does not know the actual events, but to show the worshippers themselves that they were wrong.
text.41:
The angels answered that they had never asked for such a thing; in fact, they sanctified Allah from having any objects of worship besides Him. They themselves deified Allah and sought protection from Him, so how could they possibly ask humans to worship them? They explained that it was the jinn or devils who always misled humans. Thus, humans are actually mistaken when they think they are worshipping angels, because what they are worshipping are jinn or devils. Most of the people who worship jinn or devils truly believe that the jinn or devils determine human life, and therefore they deify them.

In another verse, it is explained that among those whom Allah asked whether he had ever asked people to worship him was the Prophet Isa a.s. He also denied it, asserting that he had actually asked them to worship Allah, as expressed in the following verse:

And [beware the Day] when Allah will say, "O Jesus, Son of Mary, did you say to the people, 'Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?'" He will say, "Exalted are You! It was not for me to say that to which I had no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself. Indeed, it is You who is the Knower of the unseen." I said not to them except what You commanded me - to worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord. And I was a witness over them as long as I was among them; but when You took me up, You were the Observer over them, and You are, over all things, Witness. (al-Ma'idah./5: 116-117)
text.42:
On the Day of Judgment, Allah will declare that neither those who worship other than Allah nor those who are worshipped will be able to do anything, neither benefiting nor harming others. The disbelievers who worship other than Allah will not receive help from those they worship, because those who are worshipped are indeed incapable of doing anything. Those who worship will also not be able to blame those who are worshipped, because those who are worshipped never asked them to worship them.

In the Al-Qur'an, it is stated that no one will be able to help anyone, including family or close friends, as Allah says:

On that Day a man will flee from his brother, and from his mother and his father, and from his wife and his children. For every person, that Day, will be concern enough to make him heedless [of others]. ('Abasa/80: 34-37)

Also His saying:

And no friend will ask [anything of] a friend. (al-Ma'arij/70: 10)

They will be dragged and thrown into hell and further humiliated with the words, "Taste the punishment of the Fire which you used to deny!" These words mean that they are blamed for not believing in the existence of hell when they were in the world, which will make them even more tormented. These words also mean that the punishment of hell is terrible.

Such is the recompense for those who do not heed the call of the Messenger of Allah (saw). The conveyance of this event in the Al-Qur'an aims for the disbelieving leaders of Mecca, and anyone after them, to believe so that this event will not befall them later.
text.43:
In this verse, two further accusations from the leaders of the Meccan disbelievers against Islam are explained. First, they accused the Prophet Muhammad of being merely an ordinary human being who conveyed the verses of the Qur'an to them with the intention of preventing them from practicing the polytheistic religion inherited from their ancestors. The meaning is that the Prophet Muhammad was just an ordinary human, not an angel, and did not possess any special privileges such as wealth, and so on. The Prophet Muhammad's goal was only to distance them from the religion of their ancestors. Thus, they considered the religion of their ancestors to be better than the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad.

Second, they accused the Qur'an of being a fabricated lie. The Qur'an was merely made up by Muhammad, not a revelation from Allah swt, and its contents were not true.

On the other hand, they saw the reality that many people were attracted to the Qur'an. They themselves, when reading or having the verses of the Qur'an recited to them, also felt drawn to it. When they saw the content of the Qur'an, they were convinced that it could not possibly be made by Muhammad because he did not learn from anyone and could not read or write. They became aware that their accusations against the Qur'an were wrong. This reality compelled them to look for other reasons. Finally, they accused the Qur'an of being magic, and because of its extraordinary influence, they considered its magic to be extraordinarily powerful. Such is the nature of the disbelievers, when they are no longer able to refute the truth of the Qur'an, they revile it and look for other unreasonable excuses, as Allah says:

And when they see a sign (of Allah's greatness), they mock. And they say, "This is nothing but clear magic." (ash-shaffat/37: 14-15)

His word also:

And if they (the polytheists) see a sign (miracle), they turn away and say, "(This is) continuous magic." (al-Qamar/54: 2)
text.44:
Allah refutes the accusations of the Meccan disbelievers with two reasons. First, the idolatrous religion of their ancestors is not based on a holy book from Allah; and second, that religion was not taught by His prophet. A true religion must have a holy book as the foundation of its teachings, because the human mind is not guaranteed to be correct. Allah says:

"Or have We given them a book before this to which they are holding fast?" (az-Zukhruf/43: 21)

In addition to a holy book, a religion must have a prophet sent by Allah to receive and teach the contents of that holy book. Allah says:

"Or have We sent down to them an authority which speaks of that which they have been associating with Him?" (ar-Rum/30: 35)

The idolatrous religion of the ancestors of the Meccan disbelievers has no basis in a holy book and was not taught by a prophet from Allah. Therefore, that religion is wrong, and they should not follow that wrong religion. The true religion is Islam because it is based on revelation from Allah, namely the Al-Qur'an, and conveyed by a prophet, namely Muhammad saw. They should accept the religion brought by the Prophet Muhammad.
text.45:
In this verse, Allah explains that previous communities, such as the people of Prophet Noah, the 'Ad people, the Thamud people, and others, were destroyed by Allah due to their disbelief, leaving behind only ruins or names. They denied the verses of Allah and considered His messengers to be liars, even though they were more powerful and had greater abilities and culture. The disbelievers of Mecca did not even possess one-tenth of the strength of those communities, so why would they rebel and boast as well? Are they not afraid of Allah's wrath, considering that even the more powerful previous communities were destroyed by Allah? They should take a lesson from the history of the past, because they know very well the areas of the former communities, as they pass through them day or night on their trade journeys in summer or winter, as Allah says:

And indeed, you (the people of Makkah) pass by them in the morning and at night. Then will you not reason? (ash-shaffat/37: 137-138)
text.46:
In this verse, Allah asks Prophet Muhammad to invite the disbelievers to do just one thing: to truly strive to draw closer to Allah in search of the truth. Drawing closer to seek the truth can be done individually or together with others so that they can exchange ideas. After that, they are asked to contemplate the truth of the teachings in the Qur'an, calmly, objectively, and sincerely without being influenced by desires or envy. After they have objectively contemplated it, will they still accuse the one who conveys the truth, namely Prophet Muhammad, of being untrue? Isn't the teaching of the Qur'an absolutely true? If it is true, then the bearer of the teaching is also true. They should come to the conclusion that he is, in fact, a sincere person. He only wants to remind and warn people not to go astray in this world and suffer losses in the Hereafter. He only wants people to believe and become good people, so that they are happy in this world and avoid Hell in the Hereafter. Therefore, they should be grateful to him, and not accuse him of things that are untrue.

His function as a warner is also conveyed by him in a hadith:

"Indeed, I am a warner to you all before facing a severe punishment." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ibn 'Abbas)
text.47: The Prophet Muhammad was then asked by Allah to affirm to the disbelievers that he did not expect any reward for his work in conveying the message. If there was any reward he desired, it was only that they believe. By believing, the benefit would return to them, not to him. He himself only hoped for reward from Allah for his work, not worldly gain. He hoped to receive that reward in the Hereafter, not in this world. So what other reason did they have for not accepting his call? If they still refused to believe, then they needed to know that Allah witnesses everything, so that nothing escapes His knowledge, neither the manifest, such as evil deeds, nor the unseen, such as disbelief. Therefore, those who believe and do good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise, and those who disbelieve and do evil deeds will be recompensed with Hell.
text.48:
Furthermore, Prophet Muhammad was asked by Allah to affirm to the disbelievers that Allah always casts the truth, namely planting His revelation, into the hearts of His messengers. This is also as He stated in another verse:

"(He is) the Exalted [above all] in degrees, Owner of the Throne; He sends the Inspiration by His command upon whom He wills of His servants, that he may warn [them] of the Day of Meeting." (al-Mu'min/40: 15)

Those messengers are the ones chosen by Allah. He is the Most Knowing of who is worthy to be chosen by Him. Thus, humans have no authority to question it, as He stated:

"And when a sign comes to them, they say, "Never will we believe until we are given like that which was given to the messengers of Allah." Allah is most knowing of where He places His message. There will afflict those who commit crimes debasement before Allah and severe punishment for what they used to conspire." (al-An'am/6: 124)

Because the revelation is from Allah and those who receive it are the chosen ones, then the messengers must also be truthful. Likewise, the teachings they convey, so humans should not dispute them.
text.49:
Allah then asks Prophet Muhammad to affirm to the disbelievers that the truth has come and falsehood will not return. The meaning of truth here is Islam, while falsehood is disbelief.

When the truth comes, it will crush falsehood until it is destroyed, as Allah says:

Rather, We hurl the truth against falsehood, and it knocks it out, and behold, it vanishes. And woe to you for what you describe. (al-Anbiya'/21: 18)

Thus, falsehood will disappear when the truth comes, and the truth will prevail. Allah says:

And say, "Truth has come, and falsehood has departed. Indeed is falsehood, [by nature], ever bound to depart." (al-Isra'/17: 81)

The victory of truth will prevent falsehood from reappearing, either in a new form or its original form. Returning in a new form means the death of the old falsehood being replaced by another falsehood. Returning in its original form means the revival of the falsehood that has already died. An example of the victory of truth is the conquest of Mecca, where Prophet Muhammad entered the Masjidil Haram and destroyed the idols that the disbelievers of Mecca had placed around and inside the Ka'bah. A hadith informs about this:

When the Messenger of Allah entered the Masjidil Haram on the day of the conquest of Mecca and found many idols erected around the Ka'bah, he poked one idol among the idols with the tip of his arrow and recited, "Truth has come and falsehood has vanished. Surely, falsehood is ever bound to vanish," and continued to recite this verse 49. (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

After the Islamization of Mecca, tribes throughout the Arabian Peninsula declared their Islam one by one. Then Islam continued to spread throughout the world, and will continue to triumph until the Day of Judgment. Thus, the victory of truth and the destruction of falsehood can only be realized through struggle, as Prophet Muhammad, his companions, and the leaders after them struggled. In the Hereafter, Islam is certainly true and disbelief is certainly wrong.
text.50:
Finally, Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to convey to the disbelievers that if he was wrong, then the error was from himself. But if he was right, then the truth was obtained from Allah.

This verse demonstrates the great responsibility of the Prophet Muhammad. He is responsible for the entire content of the da'wah (call to Islam) that he conveys. If he is wrong in the teachings he conveys, then he will be responsible for the error himself, without involving his ummah (community). But it is impossible for what he conveys to be wrong, because it is all from Allah, nothing is added or subtracted by him. Therefore, his responsibility is to show that what he conveys is absolutely true. Thus, the disbelievers do not need to doubt it and should believe.

If humans believe, then Allah hears them. If they worship Him, He knows and will accept it. If His servants pray, then their prayers will be answered by Him. This is because He is All-Hearing, He is also very close to humans. How close Allah is to humans, so that He hears the whispers of their hearts in the form of faith or disbelief and grants the prayers of those who pray, is depicted in the following verse:

"And We have already created man and know what his soul whispers to him, and We are closer to him than [his] jugular vein." (Qaf/50: 16)

In another verse, Allah says:

"And when My servants ask you, [O Muhammad], concerning Me - indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me. So let them respond to Me [by obedience] and believe in Me that they may be [rightly] guided." (al-Baqarah/2:186)
text.51: In this verse, it is explained that if the Messenger of Allah were to witness how the disbelievers will be terrified before Allah, then he would witness a truly tremendous event. At that time, the disbelievers will be confronted with Allah's punishment. There will be no place to escape, nor any possibility of help, or a place to take refuge. Therefore, they will be in a state of extraordinary panic. At that time, they will be easily subdued without resistance because they will be cornered in the suffocating Plain of Gathering (Padang Mahsyar).
text.52:
At that time, they repented by declaring their faith in Allah, His messengers, and the Qur'an. They declared a truly sincere faith because all the evidence they had previously doubted had become clear and proven. Such a declaration of faith is depicted in another verse:

"And if you could but see when the criminals lower their heads before their Lord, [saying], "Our Lord, we have seen and heard, so return us [to the world]; we will work righteousness. Indeed, we are [now] certain." (as-Sajdah/32:12)

Declaring faith to repent at that time is no longer possible to achieve the desired purpose, because they are already in a very distant place, namely the afterlife. In such a distant place, it is no longer possible to seek salvation. The place to seek salvation through faith and righteous deeds is in the world, but that time has passed and they can no longer be returned there. Therefore, their repentance and declaration of faith are useless and impossible to accept.
text.53: It is further explained that they can no longer seek salvation in that distant place because during their lives in the world they were utterly disbelieving. They refused to believe in Allah, His messengers, the Qur'an, and the Hereafter. The reason they refused to believe was because they hurled baseless accusations. They assumed others besides Allah to be gods, accused the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) of being a poet, soothsayer, magician, madman, and so on, declared the Qur'an to be fables, dreams, or magic, and falsely claimed that the Hereafter, along with Paradise and Hell, were lies. They declared all of this without any basis of knowledge, but only based on conjecture. This conjecture is likened to a person throwing something unclear randomly from a distant place. He does not know whether the throw hits the target or not. In al-Kahf/18:22, this action is depicted with the expression: *rajman bil-gaib*, which means aiming at something unclear randomly or guessing at something without any basis whatsoever.
text.54:
In this verse, it is explained that between that person and their hope to repent and be freed from torment, there is a total obstruction; it is completely impossible, as if a thick, large wall has been built between the two. This longing is similar to what previous nations hoped for. Those nations were always disobedient from the beginning and only believed when disaster as punishment was already before their eyes. Of course, repentance and faith at such a forced time are not accepted, as stated in another verse:

"Then when they saw Our punishment, they said, "We believe in Allah alone and disbelieve in all that we used to associate with Him." But their faith was of no benefit to them once they saw Our punishment. [That is] the established way of Allah which has occurred among His servants. And thereupon the disbelievers lost." (al-Mu'min/40: 84-85)

They did not believe in the world because they were always doubtful about the truth of the Qur'an and hesitant to accept its truth. In fact, the Qur'an should not be doubted by humans, because it is a revelation from Allah, conveyed by Jibril, received by the Prophet Muhammad, and its contents are true. Doubt will only produce disbelief, and disbelief will only bear misery in the afterlife.
